Sun of Faith - English: After more than six years of deprivation, the Bodhisattva reflected:

Manual - English: The Buddha takes a bath. He then sleeps with a corpse as his pillow. [Chapter Cha]: The Buddha takes a bath. The five disciples eat cooked rice. Two girls named Nandā (dga' mo) and Nandabalā (dga' stobs ma) offer milk porridge to the Buddha. The golden bowl gets lost in River Nairañjanā. A nāga collects it, but Indra (brgya byin), in guise of a garuda, steals it and takes it to the realm of gods.

Sun of Faith - English: “Those who in future wish to put an end to suffering, will, in this way [i.e., the way of asceticism], extinguish all desire –
but they will achieve no more than that; they will not be able to understand or see or reach perfect enlightenment.
It is by meditating as I did in the past, in the farmers’ village, that I will be able to attain enlightenment.
But now, in the state of weakness and emaciation that I am in, I will not be able to attain it.
My body must regain its strength and splendor.”
Scene working notes: Although it is stronly implied, the Vinayavastu passage does not explicitly include this thought.

Sun of Faith - English: Letting himself draw breath freely, Siddhārtha began to eat the rice milk-soup, and other more solid fare.
He rubbed sesame oil all over his body and washed it with warm water.
Seeing the Bodhisattva’s actions, his five companions lost confidence in him.
“Alas, friends, the ascetic Gautama is wrong to renounce the path of the wise ones.
Now his quest will come to naught.”
Forsaking the Bodhisattva, the companions left for Benaras, where they became famous under the name of the Five Ascetics (Lnga sde, Pañca-bhadra-vargīya).
Little by little, the Bodhisattva regained his strength and began to wend his way to the village of Senāpurī (Sde can).
The eponymous headman there had two daughters, Nandā (Dga’-mo) and Nandabalā (Dga’-stobs),
both graced with wonderful qualities.
Since their early childhood they had heard that Siddhārtha would be the monarch of an entire universe.
They had also heard that any woman who should cultivate perfect manners and morality for twelve years,
and also prepare an exceptionally nourishing rice milk-soup and offer it to a sage weak with fasting,
that woman would become the wife of a sovereign supreme.
The young girls, who did not know that the prince had renounced the world, had carefully adhered to the above stipulations. Twelve years had just elapsed.
[Hence] The two daughters went off to milk one thousand choice cows, and had them drink their own milk.
Having milked them yet again, they gave that milk to half of the herd.
They repeated the process with those five hundred cows,
then with two hundred and fifty of them, then with 125, 63, 32, 16 and eight of them.
Next, they boiled the milk [thus obtained] after pouring it off sixteen times in a crystal bowl.
While the boiling was going on, the gods of the Pure Realm (Śuddhāvāsa, Gnas gtsang ma) dropped a restorative, one that worked instantaneously, into the decoction.
On the surface of the liquid, wheels, the symbols of good fortune, pinwheels of joy, and many other favorable signs appeared.
An itinerant ascetic named Upajivāka (Nyer ‘gro) begged to be given the drink but the girls refused to let him have it.
The following morning they decanted the milk in the crystal bowl to a chalice of solid gold.
Then, in the guise of a brahmin, Kauśika (i.e. Śakra/Indra, Brgya byin), along with Brahmā (Tshangs pa) and another powerful god of the Pure Realm approached the two daughters.
When the young girls tried to offer the precious milk-soup to the brahmin, he asked: “Is it to me that you wish to offer this milk or to one greater than I?
“To one greater than you,” replied the two in unison.
“Then offer it to the great Brahmā.”
So they offered the marvellous brew to Brahmā. He too questioned them in the same manner and then directed them to the powerful god of the Pure Realm.
This third put the same question to them as well, and then advised them to make the offering to the Bodhisattva.
The two [Nandā and Nandabalā] left to seek out the Bodhisattva.
Siddhartha had just slipped into the river Nairañjanā to take a bath.
However, his body, weakened by protracted fasting, refused to obey him.
Seeing the Bodhisattva’s inability to hoist himself up out of the water, the gods made a riverside willow-tree’s branch bend towards him.
Siddhārtha caught hold of the branch and managed to scramble out of the water. Later, wrapping himself in his shawl, he rested [on the river-bank.]
It was there that the two young women found him and made the rice-milk offering.
“Is the chalice a part of your offering as well?” inquired the Bodhisattva. “Certainly.”
The Bodhisattva drank up the concoction, rinsed the chalice of solid gold and flung it into the river, where it was received by the nāga snake-spirits.
Kauśika, disguised as a garuḍa man-eagle, stole it from them and took it to Trayastriṃśa heaven of the Thirty-Three [Gods] (Sum cu rtsa gsum) in order to turn it into an object of veneration.
Siddhārtha addressed the young women: “What do you hope to gain through this offering?”
The two women responded: “We have made a vow to marry the prince of the Śākyas once he becomes king of the entire universe.”
Siddhārtha responded: “But Siddhārtha has renounced romance. He has become a holy man!”
“ Well … then, may all his wishes come true!”
Siddhārtha felt his strength return. His body, golden brown, started to glow again, as if nothing whatever had happened [to it].
